title: Landau set
summary: In voting systems, the Landau set (or uncovered set, or Fishburn set) is the set of candidates x {\displaystyle x} such that for every other candidate z {\displaystyle z} , there is some candidate y {\displaystyle y} (possibly the same as x {\displaystyle x} or z {\displaystyle z} ) such that y {\displaystyle y} is not preferred to x {\displaystyle x} and z {\displaystyle z} is not preferred to y {\displaystyle y} .  In notation, x {\displaystyle x} is in the Landau set if ∀ z {\displaystyle \forall \,z} , ∃ y {\displaystyle \exists \,y} , x ≥ y ≥ z {\displaystyle x\geq y\geq z} .
